description: Coontail is a bushy-looking bay grass with whorls of stiff, forked leaves along densely branched stems. It grows mostly in quiet freshwater areas such as the upper Chesapeake Bay and rivers, streams, lakes and ponds throughout the Bay watershed. Usually reproduces asexually when stem fragments break off in autumn, overwinter on the bottom and develop into new plants in spring
Sexual reproduction takes place in late summer, when flowers are fertilized underwater and produce smooth rounded seeds

notes: ponds can become choked with this

description: larvae settle on the river bottom September- March and then again in July.
